articles.headline: Two Men Acquitted of Plotting to Kidnap Michigan Governor in High-Profile Trial
articles.snippet: The acquittals, along with mistrials in cases against two other men, were significant setbacks for federal prosecutors, who have promised to focus on domestic terrorism.
articles.abstract: The acquittals, along with mistrials in cases against two other men, were significant setbacks for federal prosecutors, who have promised to focus on domestic terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — It was one of the country’s highest-profile domestic terrorism cases: An alleged plot to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, eliminate her security detail and perhaps touch off a civil war. But after a trial in which prosecutors portrayed the four defendants as threats to democracy, jurors on Friday acquitted two of the men and said they were unable to reach verdicts for the two others.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Russian Blunders in Chernobyl: ‘They Came and Did Whatever They Wanted’
articles.snippet: Tank treads ripped up the toxic soil, bulldozers carved trenches and bunkers, and soldiers spent a month camped in — and dug into — a radioactive forest.
articles.abstract: Tank treads ripped up the toxic soil, bulldozers carved trenches and bunkers, and soldiers spent a month camped in — and dug into — a radioactive forest.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — As the staging ground for an assault on the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, one of the most toxic places on earth, was probably not the best choice. But that did not seem to bother the Russian generals who took over the site in the early stages of the war.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: Pro-Trump Rally Planner Is Cooperating in Justice Dept.’s Jan. 6 Inquiry
articles.snippet: Ali Alexander, who was a key figure in the “Stop the Steal” movement, said he had received a grand jury subpoena and would assist the expanding investigation.
articles.abstract: Ali Alexander, who was a key figure in the “Stop the Steal” movement, said he had received a grand jury subpoena and would assist the expanding investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ali Alexander, a prominent organizer of pro-Trump events after the 2020 election, has agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department’s investigation of the attack on the Capitol last year, the first high-profile political figure known to have offered assistance to the government’s newly expanded criminal inquiry.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Missile Strike in Eastern Ukraine Kills 50 Awaiting Train to Escape
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s president blamed Russia for the latest atrocity in the six-week-old war, calling the Russian invasion force “an evil that has no limits.” Moscow denied responsibility.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s president blamed Russia for the latest atrocity in the six-week-old war, calling the Russian invasion force “an evil that has no limits.” Moscow denied responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: One moment, they were packed onto the platforms at the Kramatorsk train station, hundreds of women, children and old people, heeding the pleas of Ukrainian officials imploring them to flee ahead of a feared Russian onslaught.
articles.byline: By Megan Specia and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Spurred by Putin, Russians Turn on One Another Over the War
articles.snippet: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.
articles.abstract: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marina Dubrova, an English teacher on the Russian island of Sakhalin in the Pacific, showed an uplifting YouTube video to her eighth-grade class last month in which children, in Russian and Ukrainian, sing about a “world without war.”
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: Trying Everything, Even Lettuce, to Save Florida’s Beloved Manatees
articles.snippet: Pollution has killed the sea grass that manatees feed on, and they are starving to death in large numbers. Extraordinary intervention may not be enough to protect them.
articles.abstract: Pollution has killed the sea grass that manatees feed on, and they are starving to death in large numbers. Extraordinary intervention may not be enough to protect them.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIAN RIVER LAGOON, Fla. — At first, the manatees stayed away from the romaine lettuce.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Eve Edelheit

articles.headline: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
articles.snippet: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia reorganized the command of its flagging offensive in Ukraine on Saturday, selecting for the mission a general accused of ordering strikes on civilian neighborhoods in Syria, as Western nations poured more weapons into the country in anticipation of a renewed Russian assault in the east.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Disagreement and Delay: How Infighting Over the Border Divided the White House
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has furiously debated how — and whether — to unravel Trump-era immigration policies.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has furiously debated how — and whether — to unravel Trump-era immigration policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden was livid.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Why Calls for War Crimes Justice Over Ukraine Face Long Odds
articles.snippet: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
articles.abstract: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
articles.lead_paragraph: This past week, as Ukrainian forces retook the town of Bucha to find its streets littered with the bodies of bound and shot civilians, and as rockets rained on a train station packed with fleeing families, killing dozens, two words were on the lips of diplomats, world leaders and rights groups: war crimes.
articles.byline: By Max Fisher

articles.headline: The Home Cooks (and Start-Ups) Betting on Prepared Meals
articles.snippet: Tens of billions of dollars are being spent on what, where and how consumers will eat in the coming years. Laws and regulations aren’t always keeping up.
articles.abstract: Tens of billions of dollars are being spent on what, where and how consumers will eat in the coming years. Laws and regulations aren’t always keeping up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several days a week, Jullet Achan moves around the kitchen of her apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, stirring up dishes from her Surinamese background: fragrant batches of goat curry, root vegetable soup and her own take on chicken chow mein.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Few Cars, Lots of Customers: Why Autos Are an Inflation Risk
articles.snippet: Economists are betting that supply chains for all kinds of goods will heal, shortages will ease and price gains will slow. Cars are a wild card in those forecasts.
articles.abstract: Economists are betting that supply chains for all kinds of goods will heal, shortages will ease and price gains will slow. Cars are a wild card in those forecasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corina Diehl is eager for more sedans and pickup trucks to sell her customers in and around the Pittsburgh area, but as the pandemic enters its third year, cars remain in short supply and the squeeze on inventory shows no sign of abating.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: A College Fights ‘Leftist Academics’ by Expanding Into Charter Schools
articles.snippet: Hillsdale College is building a national charter school network. Tennessee invited the college to start 50 of them, using public funds.
articles.abstract: Hillsdale College is building a national charter school network. Tennessee invited the college to start 50 of them, using public funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: With only 1,500 students on a small-town campus in southern Michigan, Hillsdale College is far from the power corridors of government and top-ranked universities.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: The Fortunes of MacKenzie Scott
articles.snippet: Three decades after worrying about making rent, she is now giving away billions — all while trying to keep herself out of the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Three decades after worrying about making rent, she is now giving away billions — all while trying to keep herself out of the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire philanthropist MacKenzie Scott once recounted, in a television interview, a Chinese folk tale sometimes known as “The Lost Horse.” The story is about the reversals of fortune a farmer experiences after his prized stallion runs away. It can also be read as a summary of her philosophy.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: A Stricken Ukrainian City Empties, and Those Left Fear What’s Next
articles.snippet: After the deadly strike on the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, those who stayed behind are grim about the future: “We think we will be swept off the face of the earth.”
articles.abstract: After the deadly strike on the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, those who stayed behind are grim about the future: “We think we will be swept off the face of the earth.”

articles.headline: Crypto Industry Helps Write, and Pass, Its Own Agenda in State Capitols
articles.snippet: In the absence of federal regulations, crypto lobbyists and executives are going state by state to get favorable rules enacted. Many lawmakers have been willing partners.
articles.abstract: In the absence of federal regulations, crypto lobbyists and executives are going state by state to get favorable rules enacted. Many lawmakers have been willing partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The debate took less than four minutes.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Before Giving Billions to Jared Kushner, Saudi Investment Fund Had Big Doubts
articles.snippet: Before committing $2 billion to Mr. Kushner’s fledgling firm, officials at a fund led by the Saudi crown prince questioned taking such a big risk.
articles.abstract: Before committing $2 billion to Mr. Kushner’s fledgling firm, officials at a fund led by the Saudi crown prince questioned taking such a big risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six months after leaving the White House, Jared Kushner secured a $2 billion investment from a fund led by the Saudi crown prince, a close ally during the Trump administration, despite objections from the fund’s advisers about the merits of the deal.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: New Era Begins at Warner Bros., Tinged With Nostalgia
articles.snippet: With a new owner, the 99-year-old movie studio appears headed back to its traditional sweet spot as an entertainment company. But the business of Hollywood is no longer the same.
articles.abstract: With a new owner, the 99-year-old movie studio appears headed back to its traditional sweet spot as an entertainment company. But the business of Hollywood is no longer the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — By 2018, almost every golden-age Hollywood studio had been conquered by outside forces.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Macron to Face Le Pen for President as French Gravitate Toward Extremes
articles.snippet: President Emmanuel Macron and the hard-right leader Marine Le Pen will compete for a second time in a runoff on April 24.
articles.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron and the hard-right leader Marine Le Pen will compete for a second time in a runoff on April 24.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron will face Marine Le Pen, the French far-right leader, in the runoff of France’s presidential elections.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen

articles.headline: Truck Makers Face a Tech Dilemma: Batteries or Hydrogen?
articles.snippet: Under pressure to cut emissions, truck manufacturers are choosing between batteries and hydrogen fuel cells. Wagering incorrectly could cost them billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to cut emissions, truck manufacturers are choosing between batteries and hydrogen fuel cells. Wagering incorrectly could cost them billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before war in Ukraine sent fuel prices through the roof, the trucking industry was under intense pressure to kick its addiction to diesel, a major contributor to climate change and urban air pollution. But it still has to figure out which technology will best do the job.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Shift to Support Hague Court as It Investigates Russian Atrocities
articles.snippet: The government is hamstrung from helping the world’s war-crimes court by two laws and a policy aimed at barring it from charging Americans.
articles.abstract: The government is hamstrung from helping the world’s war-crimes court by two laws and a policy aimed at barring it from charging Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is vigorously debating how much the United States can or should assist an investigation into Russian atrocities in Ukraine by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage

articles.headline: China’s Echoes of Russia’s Alternate Reality Intensify Around the World
articles.snippet: China’s officials and state media are increasingly parroting Russian propaganda organs on the war in Ukraine, undercutting U.S. and European diplomatic efforts, even after the killings in Bucha.
articles.abstract: China’s officials and state media are increasingly parroting Russian propaganda organs on the war in Ukraine, undercutting U.S. and European diplomatic efforts, even after the killings in Bucha.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Twitter put up a warning message atop a Russian government post denying civilian killings in Bucha, Ukraine, last week, China’s state media rushed to its defense. “On Twitter @mfa_russia’s statement on #Bucha got censored,” wrote Frontline, a Twitter account associated with China’s official English-language broadcaster, CGTN.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Steven Lee Myers and John Liu

articles.headline: Bucha’s Month of Terror
articles.snippet: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Daniel Berehulak and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: A One-Woman Rescue Squad for Homeless Students
articles.snippet: The work of Norma Mercado, a Texas school system’s point person for dealing with homeless young people, is benefiting from a big but temporary surge in federal funding.
articles.abstract: The work of Norma Mercado, a Texas school system’s point person for dealing with homeless young people, is benefiting from a big but temporary surge in federal funding.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle and Tamir Kalifa
